conclusion: Choose the positive x-direction to be the direction in which the bullets are fired (toward the target on cart B).
Cart A therefore has ground velocity vA = –v1 (to the left).
Cart B has ground velocity vB = +v2 (to the right).
Every bullet leaves the muzzle with ground speed v0 toward +x.
The firings are separated by a time interval Δt0.
Label the first two bullets “#1” (fired at t = 0) and “#2” (fired at t = Δt0).
Bullet #1 position for all t ≥ 0 is x1(t) = v0 t.
Cart A (and the muzzle) at t = Δt0 is at xA(Δt0) = (–v1) Δt0.
Bullet #2 starts from x = –v1 Δt0 at t = Δt0 and afterwards moves with speed v0, so for t ≥ Δt0, x2(t) = v0 t – (v0 + v1) Δt0.
Separation between the two bullets while both are airborne is s = x1 – x2 = (v0 + v1) Δt0.
The fixed distance between two successive bullets that are simultaneously in the air is s = (v0 + v1) Δt0.
The result is independent of cart B’s speed v2; v1 is the magnitude of cart A’s speed.
